(Sask-Forest-Fire)

An evacuation order has been lifted for 60 homes north of Prince Albert that had been threatened by a forest fire.

Crews battling the blaze got some help yesterday from Mother Nature -- cooler temperatures and higher humidity.

But fire officials say residents in the area are still on evacuation alert and must be ready to leave in short notice should conditions change. (P-A Dly Hrld)

(Sask-Party-Drugs)

Regina police are not laying charges against a member of the Saskatchewan legislature who was alleged to have used illegal drugs.

Last month a media outlet was given a recording of a telephone conversation in which a person said to be Serge LeClerc talks about drug use.

LeClerc is a former drug dealer who spent time in prison, but was later pardoned after turning his life around.

He removed himself from the Saskatchewan Party caucus when the allegation surfaced.

Justice Minister Don Morgan says he will ask the conflict of interest commissioner to review the situation. (The Canadian Press)

(Sask-Teaching-Rights)

Saskatchewan's human rights commissioner wants to introduce three new Rs to the province's education system -- rights, responsibilities and respect.

Judge David Arnot says there's an urgent need to teach these subjects starting in kindergarten and going all the way to Grade 12.

He says teaching rights and responsibilities from an early age is important to tackle human rights problems.

The commissioner says he still hears complaints about pregnant women being fired or people with service dogs being turned away from restaurants. (The Canadian Press)

(Sask-Jail-Drugs)

Saskatchewan prosecutors have stayed drug charges against two women arrested in a jailhouse drug bust.

Forty-three-year-old Laura Mae Reynolds and 42-year-old Michelle Anne Braumberger were charged following an undercover investigation into drug trafficking at the Regina Correctional Centre.

A stay means police have a year to reactivate the charges.

Two jail guards still face more than 20 charges. (CTV Reg)

(RCMP-Drowning)

R-C-M-P say the body of a boater who went missing Sunday from a lake in northern Saskatchewan has been have recovered.

Police say a search team found the body of a 19-year-old man in Deschambault Lake.

The search continues for a 16-year-old youth.(The Canadian Press)

British Columbia

Kelowna forest fire causes mass evacuation

A raging forest fire in Kelowna, B.C., has forced 5,000 people from their homes. The B.C. Forest Service said yesterday the 50-hectare blaze has destroyed three houses and is threatening at least 12 more. A large sawmill with stacks of stored lumber is also at risk.

The mass evacuation has created traffic jams along a section of Hwy. 97 as strong winds fan the growing fire. The source of the blaze, which began yesterday afternoon near a residential subdivision, is unclear.

Ontario

Young man drowned near Wasaga Beach

A man in his early 20s drowned yesterday in Nottawasaga River, near Wasaga Beach.

Ontario Provincial Police say they received a report around 4: 30 p.m. of a person lost in the river, and found the man drowned a short while later.

"He possibly fell in the river," said Sgt. Sandra Karlowski, adding that further details are still unclear.

Ottawa

Trudeau's son, Clark's daughter in TV interview

It's billed as a candid discussion between the son of one former Canadian leader and the daughter of another. Tonight, Justin Trudeau, Liberal MP for Papineau, is interviewed by Catherine Clark, whose father, Joe Clark, briefly interrupted Pierre Trudeau's long tenure as prime minister.

The interview, which airs at 7: 30 on CPAC's Beyond Politics, focuses on Justin Trudeau's personal life, family and upbringing. He talks about the impact of his parents' divorce, his father's influence on him, and the death of his brother, Michel.

Alberta

MLA turfed from caucus over health-funding row

An Alberta Tory MLA and former provincial cabinet minister has been kicked out of the government caucus after criticizing funding delays for a long-term care facility in his constituency.

Guy Boutilier (Fort McMurray-Wood Buffalo) was asked to leave Friday evening after a meeting with Premier Ed Stelmach over his public complaints, said spokesman Paul Stanway.

Boutilier spoke out after the government said construction of the facility, approved 18 months ago, would be delayed for four years.

B2Long, hot wildfire season coming; Canada is about 100 fires ahead of the 10-year average for early May ahead of a dry summer

Federal wildfire researchers say most regions in Canada could be facing a long, hot, fiery summer. Wildfire starts and the amount of land burned were below average for the first few weeks of the season, but dry weather is turning things around, said Richard Carr, a fire research analyst with Natural Resources Canada.

"We've had a long, lingering winter and a bit of a slow start to the fire season, but the numbers are higher than the same time last year."

Across the country, wildfire starts have been above average since the end of April. On the national fire danger map, the risk in almost all of the three most westerly provinces is rated at least high. Saskatchewan shows as almost entirely extreme.

Two provinces have already had their first evacuations of the year. About 40 people in Crutwell, Sask., have had to flee their homes at least twice. Seven families in Lac du Bonnet, Man., also had to leave.

Manitoba has counted 119 fires so far. Last year at this time, the figure was 27 and the year before that it was 58.

Nationally, the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre says Canada is about 100 fires ahead of the 10-year average for early May.

Although some parts of the country are flooding, much of the forested area remains dry, said Carr.

"It's pretty dry across that whole stretch, right from British Columbia to western Ontario."

Ontario has banned open fires in its northwest and Alberta has posted bans in many parks and municipalities. A ban in Saskatchewan covers Crown land in provincial parks, except in the Cypress Hills.

The Alberta government produces a map that displays how dry forests are. Almost the entire forested region of the province rates at least 89 out of 100.

More worrisome are Environment Canada's weather predictions for the summer. Although precipitation is difficult to predict and some rainy relief is expected by July, Carr said the data suggests it will mostly be hot and dry.

"There's still a fair amount of Canada that's showing drier than normal conditions," he said.

"If we get rain during that time, we might go into a lull and have a normal summer. But if it stays dry - and it looks like there's a chance that it might - we might be a busier season.

"A number of models are predicting a warm summer across North America. That's really increased."

Canada has about 8,000 wildfires every year that burn an average 21,000 square kilometres of forest. The amount burned varies widely from year to year, but federal statistics suggest that figure has been rising for the last several years.

Scientists theorize that increased wildfires will be one of the main effects of climate change as hotter weather and less predictable precipitation creates more volatile forests.

Fire conditions are tough to predict. Heavy rains, lightning strikes or gusting winds can change everything.

(Sask-Forest-Fire)

Crews appear to be getting the upper hand on a forest fire that has forced one rural municipality near prince Albert to declare a state of emergency.

Steve Roberts with the Ministry of Environment says 105 firefighters are battling the three-square-kilometre blaze.

Roberts says crews used heavy equipment and water tankers to set up fire guards, but the flames were still out of control. (The Canadian Press)

(Sask-Apartment-Fire)

The Saskatoon fire department says improper disposal of a cigarette or cigar on a lower first-floor balcony caused a fire that has left 40 people homeless.

The fire started Monday at an apartment building and caused 1.5 (m)-million dollars in damage.

An official with Quint Development Corporation, which owns the building, says preliminary reports are that the building is salvageable.

The Salvation Army helped find temporary accommodations for about half of the residents, while the rest stayed with family or friends. (CJWW)

(Sask-Deaths-Arrests)

Saskatoon police have charged two people in connection with a suspicious death.

James Busch and Simone Desjarlais each face a charge of improperly interfering with human remains.

The body of Sandra Ramsay was found Saturday in a dumpster in downtown Saskatoon.

Busch and Desjarlais are to appear in provincial court on Wednesday. (CBC)

(Missing-Boaters)

An R-C-M-P dive team is searching for two missing boaters in a northern Saskatchewan lake.

Police say seven people from the Deschambault Lake area were out on the water on Ballantyne Bay on Sunday when their boat capsized.

Five were rescued by people in another boat, but two others could not be found.

It's believed the missing boaters are between 16 and 18 years old. (CBC)

(HKN-Howe-Degree)

The University of Saskatchewan plans to recognize National Hockey League legend Gordie Howe with an honorary degree.

Howe is to be honoured at graduation ceremonies next month.

The Hall of Famer, who is regarded as one of the best ever to play the game, was born in Floral and grew up in Saskatoon.

He won four Stanley Cups with the Detroit Red Wings in the 1950s and six Hart Trophies as the league's most valuable player. (The Canadian Press)

(Prairie Update by John Cotter and Mary Jo Laforest)

RETAIL

Target at Laurentian

to open July 16

KITCHENER - The Target store in the Laurentian Power Centre in Kitchener will open July 16. The store at Ottawa Street and Strasburg Road is among 20 additional locations that will open this month, the U.S. retailer announced Thursday. The new locations, opening between July 16 and July 30, include 11 in Ontario, two each in British Columbia and Alberta, and three in Saskatchewan, the first Target stores in that province. The 48 stores Target has already in operation across the country include outlets in the Cambridge Centre mall and the Conestoga Mall in Waterloo.

AIRLINES

Major airlines report

more passenger traffic

MONTREAL - Canada's two largest airlines reported increased passenger traffic in June, but their planes flew with slightly fewer travellers as they both added capacity. Air Canada said its traffic grew 2.1 per cent on a system-wide capacity increase of 2.8 per cent. Its load factor was 85 per cent, compared to 85.6 per cent a year earlier. WestJet said its passenger traffic increased more than eight per cent in June, despite some cancellations and weakness following severe floods in southern Alberta. The Calgary-based airline said its load factor decreased for the fifth consecutive month, falling 2.2 percentage points to

76.8 per cent as capacity increased 11.3 per cent, outpacing traffic gains.

ENGINEERING

SNC-Lavalin executive

announces retirement

MONTREAL - The head of infrastructure concession investments at SNC-Lavalin is retiring just months after the engineering giant announced his shift from the position as chief financial officer. Gilles Laramee, who joined the Montreal-based company in 1986, will retire on Aug. 9. He was replaced as chief financial officer last month by Alain-Pierre Raynaud, a former executive of French nuclear giant Areva. urn:contentItem:5SBM-G6W1-JBVR-32JV-00000-00Federal natural resources researchers forecast long, hot wildfire season2018-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisWEATHER,NATIONALFederal natural resources researchers forecast long, hot wildfire seasonLong, hot wildfire season coming: researchersBob WeberThe Canadian Press

Federal wildfire researchers say most regions in Canada could be facing a long, hot, fiery summer.

Wildfire starts and the amount of land burned were below average for the first few weeks of the season, but dry weather is turning things around, said Richard Carr, a fire research analyst with Natural Resources Canada.

"We've had a long, lingering winter and a bit of a slow start to the fire season, but the numbers are higher than the same time last year."

Across the country, wildfire starts have been above average since the end of April. On the national fire danger map, the risk in almost all of the three most westerly provinces is rated at least high. Saskatchewan shows as almost entirely extreme.

Two provinces have already had their first evacuations of the year. About 40 people in Crutwell, Sask., have had to flee their homes at least twice. Seven families in Lac du Bonnet, Man., also had to leave.

Manitoba has counted 119 fires so far. Last year at this time, the figure was 27 and the year before that it was 58.

Nationally, the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre says Canada is about 100 fires ahead of the 10-year average for early May.

Although some parts of the country are flooding, much of the forested area remains dry, said Carr.

"It's pretty dry across that whole stretch, right from British Columbia to western Ontario."

Ontario has banned open fires in its northwest and Alberta has posted bans in many parks and municipalities. A ban in Saskatchewan covers Crown land in provincial parks, except in the Cypress Hills.

The Alberta government produces a map that displays how dry forests are. Almost the entire forested region of the province rates at least 89 out of 100.

More worrisome are Environment Canada's weather predictions for the summer. Although precipitation is difficult to predict and some rainy relief is expected by July, Carr said the data suggests it will mostly be hot and dry.

"There's still a fair amount of Canada that's showing drier than normal conditions," he said.

"If we get rain during that time, we might go into a lull and have a normal summer. But if it stays dry - and it looks like there's a chance that it might - we might be a busier season.

"A number of models are predicting a warm summer across North America. That's really increased."

Canada has about 8,000 wildfires every year that burn an average 21,000 square kilometres of forest. The amount burned varies widely from year to year, but federal statistics suggest that figure has been rising for the last several years.

Scientists theorize that increased wildfires will be one of the main effects of climate change as hotter weather and less predictable precipitation creates more volatile forests.

Fire conditions are tough to predict. Heavy rains, lightning strikes or gusting winds can change everything.

But Carr said conditions are lining up for a difficult summer.

"It is picking up pace now."

urn:contentItem:7VYJ-0D00-Y9NS-W12S-00000-00Severed cables mean cellphone and Internet disruptions in Yukon, NWT, B.C.2009-06-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSSevered cables mean cellphone and Internet disruptions in Yukon, NWT, B.C.ELIZABETH HAMESCP

WHITEHORSE, Yukon _ A telecommunications company is hoping a third service outage in a week will be the last for a while after customers in the Yukon, Northwest Territories and northern B.C., experienced repeated disruptions in their cellphone and Internet services.

In the past seven days, Northwestel Inc.'s fibre-optic cables were damaged on three separate occasions _ twice by construction companies and once after a cable melted during a controlled forest-fire burn.

''We're certainly aware of how it affects business,'' said spokeswoman Anne Kennedy on Wednesday. ''We know it's really frustrating for everyone.''

During road construction Tuesday, city crews in Dawson Creek, B.C., severed a fibre-optic cable belonging to Bell Canada.

Although the incident occurred outside of Northwestel's operating area, northern customers were unable to use their cellphones and make long-distance calls to the south.

Long-distance phone services within Northwestel's operating area, local phone services, and the Internet were available, but were slower than normal.

Northwestel re-routed telecommunications traffic to alternate paths and systems.

''We were able to talk to Telus and Bell and find other facilities that they had available that were able to carry our traffic,'' Kennedy said.

Bell began making repairs and all services were restored in about five hours.

Last Wednesday, a clearly marked fibre-optic cable owned by Northwestel was damaged by contractors at M'Clintock River Bridge, knocking out voice and data services to Yukon customers.

Last Sunday night, a controlled burn near the Smith River forest fire in northern B.C. melted a cable, also owned by Northwestel.

That meant customers were unable to make long-distance calls to the south, and their cellphones and Internet service were also disrupted.

''There's really nothing we can do,'' Kennedy said about preventing the repeated outages.

She said Northwestel routinely issues warnings to construction companies about digging in areas that have cables and did so in the case of the severed Northwestel cable at M'Clintock River Bridge. (Whitehorse Star)

urn:contentItem:5V8M-6921-F103-319H-00000-00Ymir watershed society appeals to Premier Horgan2019-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSYmir watershed society appeals to Premier Horgan

Ymir residents are taking their concerns about proposed logging in their watershed to Premier John Horgan.

In a letter released Thursday, the Ymir Community Watershed Society details what it refers to as "procedural unfairness" in its communications with BC Timber Sales (BCTS) regarding development plans in the Quartz Creek watershed.

BCTS has said it plans to log in the area of the watershed, which is Ymir's only water source.

"It is very clear that our concerns are not being heard by local BC Timber Sales staff in Castlegar, and so we're appealing to a higher level of government," said society spokesperson Jason Leus.

The letter, which was also addressed to Doug Donaldson, Minister of Forests, Lands and Natural Resources and can be seen at the bottom of this story, alleges six ways BCTS has failed to address local concerns. They include:

• BCTS has not considered or committed to an alternate water source for the community if logging damages Quartz Creek. Leus said a short-term emergency plan drafted before Christmas only details day-to-day operations and doesn't address secondary water supplies or forest fire contingencies.

• BCTS has continued to operate as though the development is inevitable.

"We're talking about a process of engagement with the community of Ymir and a complete disregard for that process," said Leus. "If at the beginning of the process we are told it's not a case of if but when, it clearly illustrates that there is in fact no process."

• BCTS is not using site-specific hydrometric data to assess Quartz Creek, and has also rejected the society's proposal to apply for funding to pay for an independent assessment. Leus said BCTS used data from 14 other watersheds for its own assessment.

"The conclusion is that everything is going to be fine. But again, there's no contingency plan and it is Ymir's only source of potable and fire hydrant water. So without it, we have no Ymir."

• BCTS has not communicated with the public and told the society it would be too costly to pay for assessment authors Alan Bates and Lars Uunila to answer written questions about their work.

• All the risk of the plan is entirely on Ymir, and that a BCTS employee suggested in the event logging affects water supply that "residents could adapt by reducing their individual water consumption."

To illustrate how little water Ymir currently has, Leus, a volunteer firefighter, said the current supply could be entirely expended on a single residential house fire.

"We are dealing with the least possible amount of supply we can get by with currently. If our supply is damaged or reduced at all by quantity, we're in dire straits."

• Finally, that BCTS did not consider the 5,000-plus letters it received during a referral period from June to August 2017, and that only 60 were responded to.

Leus said a new BCTS plan changes the proposed road network, which requires another referral process. The deadline for feedback is Feb. 9.

The Star forwarded the letter to BCTS timber sales manager George Edney. In response, a spokesperson for the forestry ministry said in an email that BCTS has a meeting scheduled with the society and the Regional District of Central Kootenay on Feb. 12.

The email confirmed two assessments have already been done, and that a third focused on the potential for acid rock and mineralized drainage is underway, but did not specifically reply to the letter's allegations.

Leus said he hopes the society's letter puts Ymir's battle on the provincial stage.

"There is a fundamental injustice at work here where the community of Ymir is forced to take all of the risk from this project while BCTS and the province of British Columbia is getting all the gain, all the reward. This is one of the most upsetting things about this thing."

BURNABY, BRITISH COLUMBIA--(Marketwired - Aug. 9, 2017) - By locking out its unionized staff, Pacific Blue Cross (PBC) is only hurting its corporate brand and weakening the company with service disruptions and a mounting backlog of unprocessed benefit claims, union leaders told a picket line rally in support of CUPE Local 1816 outside PBC's head office late this afternoon.

"Pacific Blue Cross and its CEO, Jan Grude, will of course blame the union for a situation that now sees us more than a month into a lockout with no end in sight," said CUPE BC President Paul Faoro.

"But let's remember: they're the ones who started this by trying to roll back retiree benefits for their employees. They're the ones who locked out their workers. They're the ones who introduced unilateral changes to working conditions by cancelling sick time, flex time and family responsibility leave and by refusing to recognize seniority in promotions. And they're the ones who ignored PBC Society bylaws by postponing the AGM. Did they not think there would be consequences?"

BC Federation of Labour President Irene Lanzinger said that PBC has no one to blame but itself for the service disruptions.

"Pacific Blue Cross has always prided itself on being a 'progressive' benefits provider," said Lanzinger, "but a company that takes an all-or-nothing approach to bargaining, and then locks out its workers just because they won't take concessions, is not being progressive.

"A company that tramples on the democratic rights of its members by cancelling its AGM, just because its board of directors is feeling the heat, is not being progressive. What kind of message does this send to plan subscribers -- especially families on fixed incomes who just want to have their prescription drugs and their kids' dental work paid for?"

CUPE 1816 President Beth Miller said that, later this week, PBC members will be able to visit a new page on CUPE BC's website where they can tell the company to put a stop to service delays by ending the lockout and negotiating a fair deal for PBC staff as well as uncanceling the company's previously scheduled September 7 AGM.

Also at the rally, locked out CUPE 1816 members thanked members of the public for their support throughout the lengthy labour dispute and presented a $1,000 cheque to the Canadian Red Cross for B.C. forest fire relief, the result of donations collected on the picket line.

urn:contentItem:5V8M-6921-F103-319G-00000-00Ymir watershed society appeals to Premier Horgan2019-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSYmir watershed society appeals to Premier HorganTyler Harper

Ymir residents are taking their concerns about proposed logging in their watershed to Premier John Horgan.

In a letter released Thursday, the Ymir Community Watershed Society details what it refers to as "procedural unfairness" in its communications with BC Timber Sales (BCTS) regarding development plans in the Quartz Creek watershed.

BCTS has said it plans to log in the area of the watershed, which is Ymir's only water source.

"It is very clear that our concerns are not being heard by local BC Timber Sales staff in Castlegar, and so we're appealing to a higher level of government," said society spokesperson Jason Leus.

The letter, which was also addressed to Doug Donaldson, Minister of Forests, Lands and Natural Resources and can be seen at the bottom of this story, alleges six ways BCTS has failed to address local concerns. They include:

• BCTS has not considered or committed to an alternate water source for the community if logging damages Quartz Creek. Leus said a short-term emergency plan drafted before Christmas only details day-to-day operations and doesn't address secondary water supplies or forest fire contingencies.

• BCTS has continued to operate as though the development is inevitable.

"We're talking about a process of engagement with the community of Ymir and a complete disregard for that process," said Leus. "If at the beginning of the process we are told it's not a case of if but when, it clearly illustrates that there is in fact no process."

• BCTS is not using site-specific hydrometric data to assess Quartz Creek, and has also rejected the society's proposal to apply for funding to pay for an independent assessment. Leus said BCTS used data from 14 other watersheds for its own assessment.

"The conclusion is that everything is going to be fine. But again, there's no contingency plan and it is Ymir's only source of potable and fire hydrant water. So without it, we have no Ymir."

• BCTS has not communicated with the public and told the society it would be too costly to pay for assessment authors Alan Bates and Lars Uunila to answer written questions about their work.

• All the risk of the plan is entirely on Ymir, and that a BCTS employee suggested in the event logging affects water supply that "residents could adapt by reducing their individual water consumption."

To illustrate how little water Ymir currently has, Leus, a volunteer firefighter, said the current supply could be entirely expended on a single residential house fire.

"We are dealing with the least possible amount of supply we can get by with currently. If our supply is damaged or reduced at all by quantity, we're in dire straits."

• Finally, that BCTS did not consider the 5,000-plus letters it received during a referral period from June to August 2017, and that only 60 were responded to.

Leus said a new BCTS plan changes the proposed road network, which requires another referral process. The deadline for feedback is Feb. 9.

The Star forwarded the letter to BCTS timber sales manager George Edney. In response, a spokesperson for the forestry ministry said in an email that BCTS has a meeting scheduled with the society and the Regional District of Central Kootenay on Feb. 12.

The email confirmed two assessments have already been done, and that a third focused on the potential for acid rock and mineralized drainage is underway, but did not specifically reply to the letter's allegations.

Leus said he hopes the society's letter puts Ymir's battle on the provincial stage.

"There is a fundamental injustice at work here where the community of Ymir is forced to take all of the risk from this project while BCTS and the province of British Columbia is getting all the gain, all the reward. This is one of the most upsetting things about this thing."

urn:contentItem:5W1P-5PX1-JBVR-32PT-00000-00Today in History - May 152019-05-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNATIONALToday in History - May 15Today in History - May 15The Canadian Press

Today in History for May 15:

On this date:

In 1248, Archbishop Konrad von Hochstaden laid the cornerstone for a cathedral in Cologne, Germany. The Gothic masterpiece, which was not completed until 1880, was hit 14 times by bombs during the Second World War but did not collapse. Today it is a UNESCO world heritage site.

In 1556, Protestant leader John Knox appeared at the Church of Blackfriars in Edinburgh to face charges of heresy. The Catholic bishops had hoped to humble him. Instead he turned the tables and scored a stunning triumph. He later led the Reformation in Scotland.

In 1718, James Puckle, a London lawyer, patented the world's first machine-gun.

In 1800, Britain's King George III escaped two assassination attempts in one day.

In 1814, during the war of 1812, about 500 U.S. troops crossed the border into Canada from Erie, Pa., and destroyed the town of Port Dover.

In 1879, a protective tariff was adopted by Canada as national policy.

In 1885, the North-West Rebellion ended when Metis leader Louis Riel surrendered in Batoche, Sask.

In 1912, the boundaries of Manitoba, Ontario and Quebec were extended.

In 1919, the Winnipeg General Strike began and the city was paralyzed for 41 days. An armed charge by the RCMP on June 21, which became known as "Bloody Saturday," killed one and injured 30. The Robson Commission, which later investigated the walkout by 30,000 workers, found it had been aimed only at improving wages and labour's bargaining position. But most government bodies feared a Bolshevik revolution was brewing. A number of labour leaders were jailed under wartime sedition laws, which were not repealed until 1936.

In 1930, registered nurse Ellen Church, the first airline stewardess, went on duty aboard an Oakland-to-Chicago flight operated by Boeing Air Transport (a forerunner of United Airlines).

In 1940, the first nylon stockings went on sale in Wilmington, Delaware, where 780,000 pairs were sold the first day. The material was developed by a scientist at DuPont, which is based in Wilmington.

In 1941, New York Yankees outfielder Joe DiMaggio began his record 56-game hitting streak with a single off Edgar Smith of the Chicago White Sox.

In 1944, 14,000 Jews from Munkacs, Hungary, were deported to the Auschwitz concentration camp in Nazi occupied Poland.

In 1948, the day-old state of Israel was attacked by Transjordan, Egypt, Syria, Iraq and Lebanon.

In 1956, an RCAF airplane crashed into the Grey Nuns' Home for the Aged at Orleans, Ont., killing 15 people, including 11 Roman Catholic nuns.

In 1957, Britain detonated its first atomic bomb in the Pacific.

In 1970, the International Olympic Committee expelled South Africa. The ban was lifted in 1993 after South Africa moved toward a multi-racial democracy.

In 1972, U.S. Democratic presidential candidate George Wallace was shot and left paralyzed while campaigning in Maryland.

In 1988, Soviet troops began their withdrawal from Afghanistan, almost nine years after their invasion.

In 1991, French President Francois Mitterrand appointed Edith Cresson to be the country's first female prime minister.

In 1992, Olympia and York Developments asked the courts for bankruptcy protection for its Canadian properties. The world's largest commercial landlord had been hit hard by declining real estate prices.

In 1995, China conducted an underground nuclear test, just days after it had agreed to an extension of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

In 2006, the U.S. restored full diplomatic relations with Libya.

In 2006, Iraqi officials formally charged Saddam Hussein with crimes against humanity, including the torture of women and children, murder and the illegal arrest of 399 people in a crackdown against Shiites in the 1980's. He was later executed.

In 2007, Reuters Group PLC and Thomson Corp. agreed on terms for a merger to create one of the world's largest financial news providers.

In 2011, nearly all of the 7,000 residents of Slave Lake, Alta. had to flee when two wind-whipped wildfires damaged or destroyed a third of the town. There were no reports of deaths or injuries. (In November, the Alberta government announced that arson was the cause of the forest fire and turned the file over to the RCMP.)

In 2018, Seattle Mariners All-Star second baseman Robinson Cano was suspended 80 games for violating baseball's joint drug agreement. Cano tested positive for Furosemide, a diuretic.

In 2018, Washington State Court of Appeals ruled that photographs from the scene of Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain's 1994 death will not be made public.

urn:contentItem:5P61-3BG1-F105-62X0-00000-00Police get reinforcements for fire situation2017-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSPolice get reinforcements for fire situationKeith McNeill

By Keith McNeill

The forest fire situation with the Little Fort complex had begun just a few days earlier but Clearwater RCMP detachment was already getting good support from E Division, according to Cpl. Mark Labossiere in a report to town council on July 11.

"They called me up and asked, 'What do you need?'" the detachment's acting NCO-in-charge said.

E Division is the unit responsible for the RCMP in British Columbia.

"The community has been working with us as well," Labossiere added.

Reinforcements came from Kamloops Traffic Services and Road Safety, Kelowna, Abbotsford and elsewhere in the Lower Mainland.

They helped with the extra traffic on Highway 5 caused by the closures of Highway 97 plus to control access to and patrol areas under evacuation orders such as around Hallamore and Dunn lakes.

Other partners included conservation officers, fire departments, Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure, and Argo Road Maintenance.

At the same time, regular policing continued as before, Labossiere said.

It was important that members get time off to avoid exhaustion, he pointed out.

RCMP members keep busy

In his report to council, Labossiere said that Clearwater detachment members had investigated 483 files during the second quarter of 2017 compared to 436 during the second quarter of 2016. Traffic members investigated 99 files during the reporting period, making a total of 506 calls for service investigated from April 1 to June 30.

The detachment was not fully staffed. Sgt. Grant Simpsons was due to take over charge on July 17. The new NCO-in-charge is coming from Invermere.

Clearwater detachment and traffic service units issued a total 866 tickets and warnings during the reporting period. A total of 30 drug seizures were made, four impaired investigations resulted in driver suspensions, and 12 drivers were charged and had their vehicles impounded for excessive speeding.

Clearwater detachment members investigated 39 Criminal Code offenses and laid 31 charges during the three month period.

Melody Romeo, manager of the North Thompson police-based victims assistance program, had 16 new client referrals from April to June, making a year-to-date total of 36. She is actively involved in 22 cases.

Community policing activities include Cst. Jay Meyer and Conservation Officer Warren Chayer coaching softball, Cst. Randy Seidl being involved with Wells Gray Search and Rescue, members practicing a school lockdown in Blue River, and Cpl. Labossiere attending Canada Day celebrations in his red serge, and two members taking part in the Big Bike ride.

urn:contentItem:5NC8-1HJ1-JDH3-G24N-00000-00One year later: Red Cross president in Halifax talks lessons learned from Fort McMurray wildfires2017-04-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisMETRO NEWS | NEWS | HALIFAXPg. 0One year later: Red Cross president in Halifax talks lessons learned from Fort McMurray wildfiresYvette d'Entremont - Metro

As the first anniversary of the Fort McMurray wildfire approaches, the Canadian Red Cross' president and CEO was in Halifax to share lessons learned from the most expensive disaster in Canadian history.

"Never could we have imagined that what took place in those first early days of the response would revolutionize the way the Red Cross works in disasters," Conrad Sauvé told a crowd of invited guests during a luncheon at Halifax City Hall on Wednesday.

As the disaster unfolded last May, the Red Cross was asked by the Alberta government to register members of the community of Fort McMurray. This was a challenge, as the community had been completely evacuated.

"When evacuees fled they spread around the country, some evacuating to shelters in Edmonton and Calgary while others travelled across the country, many to here in Nova Scotia and throughout Atlantic Canada to stay with family and friends," Sauvé said.

The organization's team developed an online system that registered 80,000 people via 13 call centres across the country (including one in HRM).

"While registration is a vital aspect in any response, in the case of Fort McMurray it was a game changer. It paved the way for robust real-time needs assessment but also for the largest, fastest cash transfer ever done in Red Cross history," Sauvé explained.

In the first week following the wildfires, the Red Cross raised $50 million. In two days, that $50 million was distributed via email cash transfers to the majority of those evacuated. Sauvé said many evacuees described the funds as a "lifeline" during an extremely difficult time.

"It's a tremendous Canadian success story," he said.

Gavin Giles, national vice chairman of the Canadian Red Cross board and a Halifax lawyer, said the silver lining that came from the disaster was the unprecedented response that has helped shape the way future emergencies will be dealt with in Canada.

"With disaster frequency on the rise and the annual spring flooding and then summer forest fire seasons almost upon us, the Canadian Red Cross has been putting a lot of thought into lessons from the Fort McMurray fires and other recent emergencies," Giles said.

"Today is really about how individuals, governments, corporate Canada and community organizations can work together now to be ready for what is surely and sadly ahead of us."

THUNDER BAY, Ont. _ The Ministry of Natural Resources is monitoring the quickly melting snow and drying forests, and is preparing to bring firefighting resources on line as needed.

''(Right now) we're proceeding for a normal start to the fire season in the West Fire Region,'' Deb MacLean, a fire information officer based at the Dryden Fire Management Centre, said Monday.

The 2010 forest fire season officially begins April 1.

FireRanger crew leaders will start work at the beginning of April, and by mid-April crew members will begin showing up.

But if there is an early start to the season, fire resources will be brought on earlier to respond to that change, she said.

''We have had a dry winter and if the trend continues there may be a dry spring,'' she said.

''Of course the weather forecast is always short term and spring rains could offset the dry conditions.

Human behaviour can also affect the early spring fire situation, she said.

''If people begin their spring burning of brush and grass piles in and around their rural residences and cottages under drier-than-normal conditions, their fires run a higher risk of escaping and becoming wildfires,'' she said.

The ministry is cautioning people that we're heading into spring with below normal winter snow levels and a quick melt could result in higher fire hazards.

Last year, the ministry spent $92 million on fire operations across the province during the forest fire season, compared to $85 million the previous year.

There were 384 fires in Ontario between April 1 and Oct. 31, 2009, that burned 206 square kilometres, which was the second-lowest number of fires in the past 50 years.

In 2008, 341 fires blackened 13 square kilometres of forestland _ the lowest on record.

MacLean said the past two seasons' low fire numbers were primarily due to cool, wet weather which helped reduce the chance of ignition by lightning strikes and of recreational fires spreading.

The West Fire Region recorded 194 fires that burned 139 square kilometres, while the East Fire Region recorded 190 fires that burned 67 square kilometres.

A17</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Indian band plays waiting game as forest fire rages near village</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Brian McAndrew Toronto Star</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>SANDY LAKE, ONT.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>SANDY LAKE, Ont. - The church bells won't ring today in this remote Northern OntarioIndian settlement.</p><p nitf:lede="true">And as four major forest fires continue burning out of control in the Red Lake district, the 1,300 residents will pray the bells remain silent until the threat of one fire burning just north of their 60-year-old community subsides.</p><p nitf:lede="true">If the bells toll it means they must gather their most precious belongings and gather at the long gravel airstrip for evacuation.</p><p>Rain yesterday helped ease the threat of evacuation for the natives of Sandy Lake and helped contain other blazes throughout the province.</p><p>Although the threat has eased slightly in Ontario, 71 forest fires continue to burn in Quebec, including 14 out of control.</p><p>Roar back</p><p>In Sandy Lake, meanwhile, residents fear a return of the unseasonably hot, dry weather, with temperatures soaring above 30C (86F), will bring the fires raging back to life.</p><p>"The fire will spring up again. It won't take too long," Sandy Lake band chief Josias Fiddler told The Toronto Star from his home 200 kilometres (125 miles) north of the town of Red Lake.</p><p>For the past two days the 32,500-hectare (80,000-acre) fire stayed at least six kilometres (10 miles) from Sandy lake.</p><p>But in this tiny impoverished community, inaccessible by road, residents can smell the smoke as it drifts through the settlement.</p><p>"A few days ago there was some worry because the fire was northeast of here and ashes began to fall here," Fiddler said. "There was some worry, but people haven't panicked."</p><p>Sixty, mostly elderly band members suffering respiratory and heart problems will be the first to leave if the settlement is evacuated.</p><p>Main blaze</p><p>More than 110,000 hectares (272,000 acres) of forest are burning out of control in the Red Lake district.</p><p>Provincial natural resource ministry officials directing firefighting operations are concentrating their efforts on just one fire, a 43,000-hectare blaze 23 kilometres (14 miles) northeast of Red Lake.</p><p>The fires have reduced the lush green north into patches of ugly charcoal scars with blackened conifers standing like spears, stripped of branches and needles.</p><p>The largest fire, Red Lake 7, has sent smoke, ash, and blackened pine needles falling onto the town of Red Lake.</p><p>Ministry officials say the fire poses no threat to the town of 3,500, but it is destroying millions of dollars worth of prime timber.</p><p>In Quebec, two of the 14 fires that are out of control are considered troublesome, including one that led to the evacuation of 850 residents of the Indian village of Waswanipi, Que., 800 kilometres (500 miles) north of Montreal.</p><p>The evacuation was ordered Thursday after clouds of smoke enveloped the community. Another 100 people in nearby Canon Lodge were also forced from their homes. Highways were closed and authorities banned all open campfires in the area.</p><p>3 killed</p><p>Three men fighting a forest fire in northern Quebec died Friday when they lost their grip on the pontoons of three aircraft evacuating a group of firemen.</p><p>Meanwhile, Red Lake 7, which began twelve days ago, has ruined at least 30,000 hectares of 100-year-old jackpine, used by the pulp and paper industry in Ontario.</p><p>The fire began along a logging road, and covered only 11 hectares (27 acres) when discovered.</p><p>High temperatures and erratic winds prevented firefighters from bringing it under control.</p><p>Three days ago, the fire doubled in size overnight. It is also burning inside Woodlands Caribou Provincial Park, a wilderness preserve.</p><p>Natural resources investigators are convinced the fire was started by human carelessness along the heavily used logging road.</p><p>"We may find the cause of the fire; we may never find out who started it," said ministry spokesman Bob Thomas.</p><p>More than 200 firefighters are battling Red Lake 7, but with no end in sight.</p><p>"It's over 100,000 acres, so we'll be here for a while. We'll be here a few more weeks at least," said fire boss Bob Elliott at the ministry base camp now at the centre of the fire.</p><p>Flames raced through the camp Thursday after firefighters were hastily withdrawn.</p><p>Band upset</p><p>The Sandy Lake band, however, is angered by the ministry's attention being devoted primarily to Red Lake 7.</p><p>They feel they have been cast aside by the ministry, which they claim is interested only in protecting the valuable forestry products.</p><p>Red Lake 5, the fire outside Sandy Lake, is burning trees without any commercial value, Thomas said.</p><p>But Fiddler said the fire, left to burn uncontrolled, is killing or driving off the wild animals that band trappers rely on for their livelihood.</p><p>Ministry officials met with the band council during the past two days to discuss the threat of the fire.</p><p>"Their definition of protection is watching the fire," Fiddler said. "They want to sit back and wait for the fire to get to us before they do anything."</p><p>After observing the fire, ministry officials decided it was no threat to the community, Thomas said.</p><p>"It's going to skirt the area. We're not at all concerned with that fire. We're not attempting suppression unless it threatens human life or private property," he said.</p><p>Camps evacuated</p><p>About 10 fishing camps in the Red Lake area were endangered by fire and the ministry asked camp owners to evacuate the nearly 80 guests.</p><p>While his lodge is shut down, Don Baughman estimated his Bow Narrows camp will lose about $2,000 daily.</p><p>After bringing 22 anglers back to the town of Red Lake, Baughman, owner of one of the largest and oldest camps in the district, said he would wait and see if firefighters can save his lodge.</p><p>"What's there to worry about? You either lose it or you don't," he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Star photo (Thomson) Firefighters crouching below (CP) - A sleeping and unfriendly giant remained a threat to Salmon Arm Friday night as gusty winds stirred the stubborn blaze, making a long and hot day for ground crews.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The 63-square-kilometre forest fire is burning in the mountains surrounding this idyllic city on the shores of Shuswap Lake despite the best efforts of firefighters.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- "There's a lot of smoke on the mountains because the winds pushed the fire into new fuel,'' said Mitzi Bushell, a spokeswoman for the B.C. Forest Service.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"But the fire has not advanced, it's burning within itself.''</p><p>A cold front blew through the area, 500 kilometres east of Vancouver, in the late afternoon. Winds picked up, reaching gusts of up to 40 kilometres an hour, but the fire was largely held along the guard that has been cut by firefighters.</p><p>Ground crews had to contend with a couple of breaches of the fire guard, but they were able to quickly contain them, said Bushell. So while the smoke swirled above the city, its residents hunkered down for what they hoped would be a quiet late summer weekend.</p><p>The wind, which lasted well into the night, combined with searing 35C heat made for tough conditions for firefighters, who continued to extinguish hot spots.</p><p>Several new fires were also reported in the East Kootenay region and south of Revelstoke, but none were threatening communities.</p><p>On Aug. 5, the Salmon Arm fire took only an hour to race down one mountain and cross a two-kilometre-wide valley to ignite slopes on the opposite side. In addition to the 300 firefighters, including 100 soldiers on the ground, two massive Martin Mars waterbombers, 14 helicopters and more than 100 pieces of heavy equipment are battling the fire.</p><p>And while residents have praised those efforts, many are starting to question why the fire ever got to this stage.</p><p>Donna Mason, who manages a houseboat rental company, said residents - especially those who lost homes - deserve an explanation from the government.</p><p>Mason's business has been largely unaffected by the fire, except for a cancellation Friday because the client's children are asthmatic.</p><p>"We've been telling people once they get out on the lake, "Go and don't come back,' '' she said.</p><p>"Lots of clients were excited and thrilled to be a part of the fire.''</p><p>Mason said her marine gas bar was fuelling boat after boat on Friday after a slowdown earlier in the week.</p><p>She is hoping the fire doesn't have a long-term effect on the all-important tourist trade in the area.</p><p>"It's definitely not going to be as pretty as it was, seeing as Salmon Arm is surrounded by the three mountains that were on fire,'' she said.</p><p>"They were beautiful, luscious and green and that's not going to be there next spring.''</p><p>Mason, who had to flee her home earlier this week, said Salmon Arm showed superior community spirit during the evacuation and she expects that will carry the city as it recovers.</p><p>"But there's certainly a lot of question of why this fire got out of control, we all watched it burn for two weeks wondering why they didn't put it out.''</p><p>Bushell said there is an independent review of how every fire is handled. She said the concerns of residents about the response to the early stage of the fire would be looked at.</p><p>Meanwhile, Peter Kilby, the evacuation co-ordinator for the fire operation, said he's pleased with the level of readiness of emergency personnel if another move order has to be issued.</p><p>But he's concerned that some people in the city of 15,000 are dropping their guard.</p><p>He said the community remains on evacuation alert and officials spent Friday reminding people in the areas most at risk to remain ready to move at a moment's notice.</p><p>"We have a concern there are a lot of people who've had a couple of nights on the couch with their feet up and a Coors in their hand watching television,'' said Kilby. About 20 rural homes were destroyed by the flames last week.</p><p>Gerree Loran, whose house is in the evacuation zone, said people are being lulled into a false sense of security. She's allowed in to the area for short periods but stays at a city hotel at night.</p><p>"It's just as bad, there's just as much smoke as a week ago,'' she said.</p><p>"This fire is burning all over the place. People don't realize the danger we're still in.''</p><p>The fire situation east of Salmon Arm also deteriorated late Friday.</p><p>Forest Service spokeswoman Karyn Zuidinga said the areas south of Invermere in the East Kootenay and Nakusp - south of Revelstoke - had received a large number of lightning strikes.</p><p>"We have a developing situation,'' she said from Castlegar, B.C. "We've got a lot of fires being reported and we've got a lot of action.</p><p>"We've got initial attack crews and the air tanker up.''</p><p>Fires also continued to burn in northwestern Alberta, parts of Saskatchewan and Northern Ontario. Hundreds of people have been removed from remote northern communities, but the situation in those provinces appears to be stabilizing.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Human behaviour can also affect the early spring fire situation, she said.

''If people begin their spring burning of brush and grass piles in and around their rural residences and cottages under drier-than-normal conditions, their fires run a higher risk of escaping and becoming wildfires,'' she said.

The ministry is cautioning people that we're heading into spring with below normal winter snow levels and a quick melt could result in higher fire hazards.

Last year, the ministry spent $92 million on fire operations across the province during the forest fire season, compared to $85 million the previous year.

There were 384 fires in Ontario between April 1 and Oct. 31, 2009, that burned 206 square kilometres, which was the second-lowest number of fires in the past 50 years.

In 2008, 341 fires blackened 13 square kilometres of forestland _ the lowest on record.

MacLean said the past two seasons' low fire numbers were primarily due to cool, wet weather which helped reduce the chance of ignition by lightning strikes and of recreational fires spreading.

The West Fire Region recorded 194 fires that burned 139 square kilometres, while the East Fire Region recorded 190 fires that burned 67 square kilometres.

urn:contentItem:5GCY-94V1-JDV5-F15N-00000-00Smoke from Western Canada wildfires reaches Toronto2015-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSSmoke from Western Canada wildfires reaches Toronto

Smoke from the wildfires burning throughout Western Canada has reached Southern Ontario.

According to Environment Canada, smog is not to blame for the recently hazy Toronto skies. Instead, the foggy skies of late are the result of forest fire smoke, high in the atmosphere above the city for the last few days, blown eastbound from Western Canada.

Geoff Coulson, a meteorologist from Environment Canada, told The Toronto Star that in addition to "fuzzier" skies, the smoke has given the sun a reddish hue at sunrise and sunset due to smoke particles scattering the light.

Though it may seem odd that fires "burning 2,500 kilometers away in Northern Saskatchewan" are causing changes in Toronto air, it is simply an indication of how, at Canadian latitudes, winds high up in the atmosphere tend to circle the earth in a West to East direction, Coulson explained.

However, despite the series of air quality advisories in affect in Vancouver, Northern Alberta, and parts of Saskatchewan and Manitoba, there are no health concerns caused by the smoke in Toronto.

"At this point in time Southern Ontario...there is no concern for surface level smoke particles," Coulter said.

Earlier this month, almost 1,000 military personnel were called in to assist with the wildfires in Saskatchewan that have forced over 5,200 people from their homes. According to the province's environment officials, 300,000 hectares are burning in high-priority areas - ten times the usual amount.

British Columbia, there have been almost 900 wildfires since the season started April 1, 184 of which are still burning. The fires have prompted the evacuation of over 100 homes, extraordinary health advisories, and one fatality, 60-year-old John Phare. who died while helping crews battle a fire north of Vancouver.

urn:contentItem:5HW3-SK01-JDV5-F506-00000-00Barn fire at farm kills 13 horses2016-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A11Barn fire at farm kills 13 horsesThe Canadian Press

Thirteen horses died in a barn fire overnight Thursday - the second such tragedy in the province in less than two weeks.

The horses were killed after flames broke out in a barn on a private farm in Mount Forest, northwest of Guelph. The fire came just 11 days after a devastating blaze in Puslinch in which 43 standardbred horses died.

"It just can't happen again. It's just too much damage, too heart-wrenching," Mount Forest Fire Chief Dave Guilbault told The Canadian Press from the scene of the latest fire.

"To have two in less than two weeks' time, I'm hoping it's just an anomaly and it's not something that's going to continue. We are definitely going to get together with the Puslinch fire department and work as a team to see how we can get involved and get more fire awareness in these farming operations."

A person who answered the telephone at the Mount Forest property early Friday said the horses that died were Arabian. Guilbault said only one horse managed to escape the fire, which began at about 10 p.m. and was largely extinguished by Friday morning, although some hot spots remained.

About 50 firefighters responded to the blaze. Some had tried to enter the barn to help the animals but had to retreat because the situation was too dangerous, Guilbault said. Firefighters also had to hold back farm staff trying to rush into the building.

"We had to control them, we had firefighters dealing with them because they wanted to go in the barn. It's just a terrible, terrible thing," he said, adding that firefighters had to deal with a strong wind fanning the flames and cold, icy conditions through the night.

Budget; EDS: UPDATES with homes being evacuated in Leetch, N.B.; SEE CP Photos CAR 101, 102; INDEX: Forestry, Environment, Social; HL:N.B. forest fire forces evacuation of homes in community of Leetch</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Michael Tutton</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>HALIFAX</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>HALIFAX (CP) - The sudden end of a snow-laden, extended winter has brought a fresh problem to the Maritimes: tinder dry forests that have ignited into a rash of spring fires.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Forestry experts say the rapid melt of snow piled in forests has increased the fire risk because most of the moisture evaporated instead of seeping into the ground.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- The quick onset of warm, spring weather and less than half the amount of rainfall in April than a year ago has left branches, deadfall and the forest floor at their driest levels in years.</p><p>"We went from very little danger to moderate danger in five days,'' said Paul Gilmore, a forest fire specialist with the New Brunswick Natural Resources Department.</p><p>"The potential is there to have a large fire in New Brunswick very, very easily.''</p><p>More than 100 fires have burned in New Brunswick during the past two weeks, blackening 301 hectares. That's almost double the 65 blazes that had ignited by this time last year.</p><p>On Wednesday, seven waterbombers, including one from Newfoundland, were battling an out-of-control fire near Sheila-Tracadie, in northern New Brunswick. Homes in the tiny community of Leetch were evacuated late in the day as the fire spread.</p><p>On Tuesday, the province banned campfires and burning near woodlands. On Wednesday, low water levels in Grand Falls, N.B., forced the town to order an end to lawn watering.</p><p>Only 20 hectares of fires have burned in Nova Scotia this week. Several small fires were reported in eastern Prince Edward Island on Tuesday.</p><p>But officials throughout the region are concerned the situation could worsen if the month continues to be dry.</p><p>At the Nova Scotia Fire Centre, spokesman Dan MacKinnon said the province is considering banning campfires and grass burns if humidity levels don't increase over the next week.</p><p>"It's deceiving. You'd think everything would be wet, but it only takes a few days of dry weather to remove the moisture,'' said MacKinnon.</p><p>Ivan MacSwain, a forecaster at the Maritime Weather Centre in Dartmouth, N.S., said the next few days may bring light rain to the region, but the long-term forecast is for a month with low rainfall.</p><p>"We're calling for a dry spring,'' he said.</p><p>During the past winter, an average of three metres of snowfall in the Maritimes clogged roads, collapsed building roofs and stretched snow removal budgets to the limit.</p><p>But the first week of May saw a sudden switch to dry, warm days.</p><p>"I've seen fields of snow where you see the moisture evaporating off in waves,'' said Wade Wilson, spokesman for New Brunswick's Natural Resources Department.</p><p>Earlier this week, a fire in Earltown, N.S., destroyed a field of commercially grown Christmas trees.</p><p>Bryan Reid, a volunteer fire chief from Tatamagouche, N.S., said he seldom sees fires take off so quickly early in the season.</p><p>"If it stays as dry as it is now, we'll see fire hazard reach the extreme level before the end of May,'' Reid said.</p><p>In P.E.I., forestry officials have issued very few burning permits due to the dry conditions.</p><p>Fires in the spring are common because moisture levels in brush and trees are at their lowest levels of the year.</p><p>The high-risk period usually is over by mid-June. By the end of July and early August, the likelihood of fires rises again as forests dry out.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata The danger of forest fire is extreme because of <br/>the fine weather and lack of rainfall over the last week.</p><p>In addition, the <br/>weather forecast does not call for any appreciable quantity of rain in coming <br/>days. <br/>    The fire near Chisasibi has been under control since 5 p.m. on Sunday, <br/>May 29. However, the forest fire in the LG-4 production sector is still active <br/>and under observation, although it does not pose a threat for workers in the <br/>area. Last, several new fires caused by lightning strikes are under <br/>observation in the sector of the Relais Routier at Km 381 on the James Bay <br/>Road. <br/>    Collaboration from the general public is required to avoid any new fires <br/>in the territory of the JamDesie regional county municipality. The forest is a <br/>source of collective wealth and the location for a wide range of activities, <br/>but it is a fragile environment that is vulnerable to fire. Wood is <br/>inflammable, and it is important not to add to naturally-occurring risks of <br/>fire. urn:contentItem:5WKW-FPN1-JDH1-C1RD-00000-00Humans - not dry cedars - pose most Muskoka wildfire risk in 20192019-07-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Humans - not dry cedars - pose most Muskoka wildfire risk in 2019

MUSKOKA - Dead cedars are not the biggest wildfire threat in Muskoka.

Maimoona Dinani, a media relations officer for the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, told this newspaper that the ministry continued to assess wildfire threats and is not overly concerned about cedar conditions in Muskoka and Parry Sound.

"This is because the drying or dead cedars are not particularly widespread throughout a dense forest type of configuration which would lead to fire spread on a large scale," said Dinani.

Residents and visitors across Muskoka and Parry Sound reported widespread drying and dying cedars, both ornamental and wild, in 2018.

Some worried the trees were being attacked by a disease or invasive species, as had elm, ash and beech trees. But experts noted the culprit was actually difficult winter conditions - lots of freeze-thaw cycles, minimal snow cover and harsh winds - followed by a dry spring.

And now a particularly crispy strip of not-so-evergreens, which included cedars, pines and others, sits along the Highway 11 corridor in 2019.

But Dinani reiterated the issue did not seem widespread because it may be unique to the corridor.

"Most of the cedar mortality along Highway 11 may be a result of a number of factors, including road salt, and typically only affects the trees directly adjacent to the highway which are the most exposed to salt contamination," stated Dinani. "Trees a little further in from the highway typically do not show the same mortality."

Wildland fire risk, continued the media relations office, is relatively low as a result because of the sparse nature of the damage.

"No escalated actions are being taken at this time because the cedar mortality is not particularly widespread and the risk of large, unmanageable fires is quite low," said Dinani.

But monitoring continues for general wildfire risk.

"The ministry monitors forest conditions, weather and the risk of wildland fires on a daily basis throughout the fire season. Wildland fire response resources are put in place based upon this daily monitoring," said Dinani. "Daily wildland fire response preparedness is in place across the province."

The ministry holds forest fire management agreements with area municipalities for a partnered response, if necessary.

Mike Vadlja, fire prevention officer for the Huntsville-Lake of Bays Fire Department, confirmed cedars in Muskoka were not causing any widespread concern for fire departments, either.

But forest conditions are continually monitored.

"As with any of our forested areas, the layer of dead vegetation is always a concern once things become dry," said Vadlja. "With the warmer temperatures, low humidity, higher winds and no rain, these fuels can become dry rather quickly."

He noted the area's forests were made up mostly of mixed hardwood.

"The green leaf offers somewhat of a natural protection so we do not see the fire behaviour that they may get in northern Ontario," he said.

But he continued that dry conditions and natural phenomenon still posed risks.

"We could also see fires caused by lightning strikes when conditions dry out the deeper layers of the soil," he said.

Vadlja added that the region's fire danger rating, issued by the Muskoka Association of Fire Chiefs, had steadily climbed this season.

"Residents (and visitors) are urged to use extreme caution and are urged to adhere to the no-daytime-burning rules, and make sure that any fires are completely extinguished before leaving the area," he said.

And why do humans need to use extra caution?

Because, according to Vadlja, humans are one of the biggest culprits when it comes to fires in Muskoka.

"Most of the fires attended to by fire departments in Muskoka are typically human caused and can be prevented by following the open-air burning bylaws that each municipality has," he said.

Campfires, especially, are serious threats. Cigarettes, too.

"We see a lot of fires started from campfires that have been left overnight and will stir-up and ignite the surrounding area the next day," he said. "Once things get dry, a fire can be easily ignited by a carelessly discarded cigarette as well."

The fire season, according to the Muskoka Association of Fire Chiefs, runs April 1 to Oct. 31. The association set the fire danger rating in the region to high on July 8, which meant no daytime burning allowed in Muskoka.

"You must have adequate tools and water to extinguish the fire if the need arises and you must be with your fire at all times," added the association in a media release. "Consult with your local bylaw department for outdoor burning regulations in your municipality."

The ministry reported 612 forest fires across Ontario in 2018, which was higher than a 10-year average of 410 per year. Roughly 214 forest fires had been reported for 2019 by July 11.

Call 911 to report a wildfire in Muskoka.

urn:contentItem:5P19-SMH1-F105-62D6-00000-00Lightning sparks 28 fires in Southeast Fire Centre2017-07-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSLightning sparks 28 fires in Southeast Fire Centre

Things in the Southeast Fire Centre (SFC) were relatively calm until Monday when lightning sparked 28 new fires.

"The Southeast Fire Centre experienced significant lightning," explained Karlie Shaughnessy, information officer for the SFC. "The good news is that none of these fires are threatening any structures or communities and that they all are fairly small in size."

The closest fires to Castlegar as of Wednesday afternoon were near the Waneta border crossing and north of Nelson.

A lightning-caused fire near the Pend-d'Orielle area was reported Monday afternoon. As of Tuesday afternoon it was two hectares in size.

"It saw about five millimetres in precipitation overnight [Monday], which helped the crews, so today we have a crew on site mopping up this fire," said Shaughnessy. "So they are making really good progress with it."

Fire Crews were actively working on a higher elevation fire up Duhamel Creek Tuesday and by Wednesday afternoon the fire was 100 per cent contained and in mop-up stage.

In addition to those, several fires were burning on the east side of Arrow Lake.

A fire at Mount Marshall five km southeast of Burton was being held by an initial attack crew.

A fire at Miller Creek, 10 km east of Burton was spot-fire sized.

An older fire at Woden Creek was 100 per cent contained and crews are patrolling for flare-ups.

"The situation [in the Southeast Fire Centre] is looking pretty good right now," said Shaughnessy on Wednesday afternoon.

None of the fires in the region were large enough to cause the smoke that moved into the area, which was coming from the larger fires in the Kamloops and Cariboo regions.

"The public can expect to see more smoky skies as the wind prevails from the west," said Shaughnessy.

Skies were clearer Wednesday than Tuesday, when the air quality health index reached 4. But the situation is entirely dependent of prevailing winds.

With no significant precipitation in the long-term weather forecast, conditions could worsen at any time. At press time, the weather forecast was calling for a chance of thunderstorms Wednesday evening and then again on Sunday, with hot and dry conditions in between.

A complete fire prohibition is in effect for the entire fire centre. Anyone going into the backcountry is urged to use extreme caution, especially if operating off-road vehicles as their exhaust systems can and do start forest fires.

If you see smoke coming from the forest, or a fire call the forest fire reporting line at 1-800-663-5555 or *5555 on your cell phone.

Updated fire information can be found at bcwildfire.ca.

urn:contentItem:5P0W-VHW1-F105-64NR-00000-00Billy Barker Days Festival cancelled due to wildfires2017-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSBilly Barker Days Festival cancelled due to wildfiresAutumn MacDonald

Billy Barker Days is officially cancelled due to the forest fire situation. Council requested organizers of the 44th annual family festival cancel the event out of respect for residents fleeing the flames and losing their homes. The decision came down Monday night. The rationale for this cancellation is as follows:

1. Travel is extremely limited throughout the Cariboo, with Highway 97 South closed. New road closures may occur due to the emergent fire situation, as such the EOC is recommending that any unnecessary traffic be minimized on all highways in the area.

2. The prevailing smoky conditions in the area can change rapidly, during the actual event the conditions could deteriorate. The long range forecast calls for predominantly more hot weather. This can cause medical issues for some people.

3. The RCMP are fully engaged in evacuation and traffic control (roadblocks) throughout the North Cariboo. Half of their crew is tied up on emergency issues. If Billy Barker Days were to proceed, it would be without RCMP support.

4. The Fire Department has sent a crew and a Fire Engine to assist 100 Mile House, so their ability to respond to local calls for service is limited. Our crew in 100 Mile is committed until at least Friday, July 14th and may be asked to extend their stay.

5. Currently, G.R. Baker Memorial Hospital is working over capacity due to receiving patients from other hospitals. Billy Barker Days always represents an increased work load, when their resources are already stretched.

6. While the City is not currently taking in evacuees from out of the area (with a few exceptions), this could change depending upon the needs which arise in the next several days, such as from the Green Mountain fire, fires on West Fraser road, or Nazko fires. We need to keep facilities available should the fire situation change and local support be required.

7. The Alex Fraser Park venue is already housing a number of evacuees, both people and animals. They may need even more capacity for this in the near future.

"The City of Quesnel fully supports the Billy Barker Days' Society's decision to cancel this years' event," Mayor Bob Simpson said.

"This is the right decision during this uncertain time and, our focus needs to be with those affected and those fighting tirelessly to assist and mitigate the ongoing emergent nature of the wildfire situation throughout the Cariboo."

"The Quesnel Downtown Association feels that proceeding with the Billy Barker Days Festival would put locals, visitors, and vendors in an unsafe situation and have cancelled their Gold Dust Mall event," Billy Barker Days president Maureen Murray said.

urn:contentItem:5P01-X3D1-F105-627M-00000-00Southeast Fire Centre bans campfires2017-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSSoutheast Fire Centre bans campfiresTrevor Crawley

The Southeast Fire Centre has banned campfires throughout the region to help prevent human-caused wildfires and protect public safety.

This campfire ban will remain in place until the public is otherwise notified.

The Southeast Fire Centre is currently experiencing dry conditions and fire danger ratings are generally high or extreme throughout the region. With forest fuels drying out and lightning storms in the weather forecast, it is crucial to decrease the risk of human-caused wildfires so firefighters can concentrate on naturally occurring wildfires in the region.

Prohibitions on larger Category 2 and Category 3 open fires are already in effect throughout the Southeast Fire Centre.

To learn about the differences between campfires, Category 2 open fires and Category 3 open fires, visit: www.gov.bc.ca/wildfirebans or review the open fire regulations poster at:   www.gov.bc.ca/openfireregs

Specifically, prohibited activities once the campfire ban takes effect will include:

· stubble or grass fires of any size over any area

· the use of fireworks, sky lanterns, tiki torches, chimineas, burning barrels or burning cages of any size or description

· the use of binary exploding targets (e.g. for target practice)

· the use of air curtain burners (forced air burning systems)

These prohibitions do not apply to cooking stoves that use gas, propane or briquettes, or to a portable campfire apparatus with a CSA or ULC rating that uses briquettes, liquid or gaseous fuel - so long as the height of the flame is less than 15 centimetres. The use of a campfire apparatus that does not meet these specifications is prohibited.

These prohibitions cover all BC Parks, Crown lands and private lands, but do not apply within the boundaries of a local government that has forest fire prevention bylaws and is serviced by a fire department. Always check with local authorities to see if any other burning restrictions are in place before lighting any fire.

The Southeast Fire Centre covers the area extending from the U.S. border in the south to Mica Dam in the north and from the Okanagan Highlands and Monashee Mountains in the west to the B.C.-Alberta border in the east. It includes the Selkirk Natural Resource District and the Rocky Mountain Natural Resource District.

Anyone found in contravention of an open burning prohibition may be issued a ticket for $1,150, required to pay an administrative penalty of $10,000 or, if convicted in court, fined up to $100,000 and/or sentenced to one year in jail. If the contravention causes or contributes to a wildfire, the person responsible may be ordered to pay all firefighting and associated costs.

MOUNT FOREST - There's two new chiefs in town - for a day.

Wellington North Fire Service once again held their Fire Chief for a Day contest at the six elementary schools within Wellington North, and announced the winners on Monday morning.

urn:contentItem:5P0F-VB51-JDH3-G4GS-00000-00Wildlife may survive these wildfires, if theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re fast2017-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:31ZLexisNexisNEWSWildlife may survive these wildfires, if theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re fast

People and pets first.

Property second.

Then there are all those wild animals to worry about.

There are many unknowns when assessing the impact of a forest fire on wildlife, Helen Schwantje, the BC government's top wildlife veterinarian told T he Spotlight in a telephone interview Sunday morning.

"We may never know what animals were killed and what happened," she said. "Mother Nature is pretty resilient, but this is a pretty nasty situation...there is nothing that wildlife managers can do to assist the animals until things are safe for people to go in and look."

According to Schwantje, young animals and small species are more at risk simply because they can't travel fast enough.

Large animals like moose, deer and bears can cover ground quickly and use their instincts to find safe ground.

"Do they know where the evacuation corridors are? No, but they will find their own - river courses, in other cases they will go up higher where are air is better."

Schwantje said so many different factors affect wildlife it is difficult to know which species, in which areas, will be hardest impacted.

"Woodland Cariboo could be severely impacted. They depend on old growth forests and if the old growth forests are burned there are not a lot of other places to go."

Small birds and certain species of snakes are also particularly vulnerable, she said.

In the aftermath of a fire it is also hard to judge how much an animal population has been decimated, unless that population was already under study.

"Some of the areas that are being burned currently, there is research going on there and monitoring and that will include going back and checking those populations."

Overall, the biggest impact the fires will likely have on animals is changes to habitat.

"Habitat is what all wildlife depends on."

Carnivores may suffer from a lack of food source, when smaller animal populations are eliminated, she said.

For others there might be an eventual upside.

"Moose and deer benefit from fire that allows new vegetation to grow up very quickly. In years to come those areas might eventually benefit."

Schwantje said it's important for animal lovers to understand there is not a provincially run rescue or rehabilitation program for wildlife, however the Conservation Service Office and volunteer groups play a role.

"In most cases we are not going to see animals that we can rescue or make better...If the public sees animals that are in distress or injured they should first call the RAPP line 1-877-952-7277."
